DEATH OF MEMBER
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: I wish to take this, the first opportunity which has presented itself of referring to the death of Inche Ahmad bin Ibrahim, the Minister for Labour and Member for Sembawang, which occurred on the 21st of August, 1962.

Column: 632



    On the 22nd of August, 1962, on behalf of this Assembly, I addressed a letter to his widow in the following terms:-

    I desire, on behalf of the Legislative Assembly, to express to you and members of your family, with great regret and with very deep sympathy, our expression of the sense of loss the Assembly has sustained at the sad passing of your husband.'

    In accordance with the law, I duly acquainted His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara of the resultant vacancy in this Assembly.

Tributes by Leader of the House and Opposition Leaders


    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is my sad duty to formally inform the House that the Minister for Labour, Inche Ahmad bin Ibrahim, Member for Sembawang, passed away on 21st August, 1962, barely two weeks ago.

    My colleague, the Prime Minister, has already paid a tribute to him on behalf of the people and Government of Singapore. I find it an equally difficult task, as Leader of the House, on behalf of this House, to pay our tribute to an honourable and brave colleague. The people will never know how indebted we are to him.

    In our moment of rejoicing after the verdict of the referendum was known, our hearts were filled with sorrow by the thought of how much the results of the referendum would have cheered him. Had he been alive, he would have known that he had not lived and fought to live in vain. He was in great pain and suffering. Had he asked for sedation, which the doctors would have been fully justified in giving him, he would have shortened his life. But he wanted to live on in order that he could see this referendum through with us.

    I am sure all Members of this House will wish these proceedings to be placed in the records of this House.

    I am grateful, Mr Speaker, for your message of sympathy which you sent on behalf of the House to his widow and children. They will shortly return to their kampong in Penang.

Column: 633



    It is my sad privilege, Sir, to pay this tribute to a man, by nature humble and unassuming, a man who made friends easily, who was unselfish, and who I believe was liked by all who knew him in this House since 1955.

1.05 p.m.

He was a man sincere in his desire to work for the people of Singapore, and when his Party came to power and he was made a Minister, he did his best, in spite of his failing health, to discharge his duties in the best interests of the people.

    I have known him for seven years as a political opponent, and I say truthfully he was a good man, sincere and genuinely humble.

    I am grieved to learn of the long period of physical agony that he suffered with such quiet dignity, and I would like to express a sense of personal loss and sincere condolence to his bereaved family.

"GUILLOTINE" MOTION


    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, as the House is aware, the results of the poll taken on the referendum have already been made known. However, under the law the Assembly must decide on the blank votes and on the uncertain votes that have been cast. It is necessary that a final decision should be made on the uncertain and blank ballot papers so that a formal result of the poll can be conveyed to the Government of the Federation of Malaya, the United Kingdom Government, and the United Nations Special Committee on Colonialism. It is for this reason that I have requested you, Mr Speaker, to summon this one-day sitting of the Assembly so that the House can decide on the fate of the uncertain and blank ballot papers. It is my hope, Mr Speaker, that a decision will be quickly arrived at by this House. I therefore move,

    That the proceedings on item 2 of the Order Paper for this day shall be brought to a conclusion at 6.00 p.m. today.

    Question proposed.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, we are summoned to an emergency sitting of this Assembly to enact yet another scene of the tragedy of destruction of respect and goodwill for democracy and the democratic process. This Assembly has now become a public plaything of the P.A.P. Even the time allocated for consideration of vital matters of public importance, as alleged by the Leader of the House, is now to be limited to meet the convenience of the social activities of our Prime Minister.

    If there is need for an emergency session of this Assembly, why limit it to five hours? Is it because the Prime Minister has a party at 6.30 this evening? Is it because he has decided to leave late tonight on another of his many trips, and cannot trust his colleagues to carry on without him? Is this Assembly then the Prime Minister's toy, like a yo-yo to be twisted on his finger

Column: 636

as and when he pleases? Was it not anticipated last week by the Leader of the House that there would be published a Referendum Report by the Superintendent of the Referendum? Why could he not have used some intelligent anticipation and given notice to suit the Prime Minister's convenience and his social activities for the holding of this special sitting last Monday, Sir? We could then have had a full day's hearing at least, or yesterday when the Prime Minister would have been there to guide his cohorts in the methods of dishonesty now so eminently and publicly known as the principal instrument of P.A.P policy. Why was this notice not given last week for the convening of this Assembly earlier if we had to suit the Prime Minister's convenience? Was it because, Mr Speaker, had the results of the referendum been other than they are, there would have been no sitting of this Assembly? That they waited to make quite sure that there would be no question about the blank votes and they could publish the blank votes before they could have the courage to give notice of the convening of this Assembly? The notice of sitting was given last Monday after the referendum results were known.

    The Leader of the House must have been fully conscious that there must be a sitting of this Assembly whatever the results of the referendum. Why did he not give his notice earlier?

    The motion standing in the Prime Minister's name is a motion of shameless dishonesty as well as one, in my submission, that is illegal. It is my intention, subject to your ruling, Mr Speaker, Sir, to rise on a point of order when it is called in order to draw attention to its illegality and its being ultra vires the provisions of the Referendum Ordinance, and an attempt by the Government to pass on the dirt of its own section 29 to the Opposition which has been consistently fighting it.

    It may be, Mr Speaker, you will over-rule me, in which event it will be my desire to draw attention to the perfidy of the main motion in the Prime Minister's name, to quote from Select Committee proceedings and Assembly

Column: 637

debates to show that it is the Government, not the Opposition, that is responsible for section 29. The Opposition consistently resisted it. It is the Government that must take the decision of the Assembly, not-

    Mr Speaker: Order. Is not all this relevant to the second item and not to the first item on the Order Paper?

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, I will draw attention to the various aspects which need time, and I promise you I shall merely briefly pass through them so that the Assembly can assess the amount of time necessary for the consideration of some of the salient issues raised.

    Sir, it is the Government that forced through section 29, and it is my intention to show this, and it is hoped that others will also seek to discuss this theme. Though the Government can pass a Bill to make a man into a woman, it cannot say the Opposition says that a man is a woman when the Opposition votes against it. But above all, Mr Speaker, Sir, it is my intention to draw the attention of the Government to the fact that it has the opportunity to be honest and yet have its cake, have what it wants. And whatever its tradition of dishonesty, whatever its corkscrew incapacity to go straight, here is one chance to be honest, here is one chance to act constitutionally like other civilised human beings, and here is one chance where, without costing them anything, we can so gracefully avoid utilising the dishonest provisions which they prepared. We should allow the people of Singapore to go into this merger which they want with clean hands.

    I have no doubt, Mr Speaker, that every Member of the Opposition - certainly many of them - would wish to develop some of these themes. I can see no reason why this Assembly should be treated in such arrogant fashion to suit the social engagements of the Prime Minister.

    Mr Speaker, I have a three-day case in Malacca. I cancelled it in order to be here. The Prime Minister can cancel his social engagement at 6.30 p.m.

Column: 638

and allow us adequate time for debate. I will vote against the motion limiting the time to 6.00 p.m. We are not a P.A.P. plaything.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, this so-called urgent Assembly sitting was made known to us on Monday afternoon. We were informed late Monday afternoon that there was going to be a sitting on Wednesday to discuss a matter of very urgent public importance. And this is what it is about.

    Now, if this matter, which is to be debated later, is of such urgent public importance as the Government has deemed it, then it should not limit the time of the House to its discussion. How could a matter of urgent public importance be debated and thrashed out fully within as short a time as 4½ hours?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if this "guillotine" motion is being forced through by Government's majority, it would convey the impression to the public that today's Assembly sitting has been called not to discuss a matter of urgent public importance but to put forward nothing but just plain, pure P.A.P. propaganda.

    Mr Bani: Mr Speaker, Sir, we realise that opposing this guillotine motion will not get us very far because the Government, by virtue of the fact that it has a majority in this House, is in position to carry it through. We merely wish to register our strongest protest against this guillotine motion.

    Sir, we have abstained from voting in this Chamber on guillotine motions in the past. It appears to us that guillotine motions have become the order of the day for the P.A.P. We register our strongest protest and we hope that at least in the future the Government will try to refrain from abusing its powers.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, it was not my intention to speak on this motion in reply to the hon. Members about the time for the main debate. However, the Member for Anson in his usual manner has launched into a tirade which has brought in my social engagements and

Column: 639

other activities, and I feel that in fairness, I should say: yes, the matter was anticipated and it was duly discussed by us in Cabinet.

    As you know, the Leader of the House consulted the officials of the Assembly about the relevant provisions and we did this as a calculated and deliberate move, and we believe it is the correct move. The campaign was going on right to its end on Saturday, and we did not want to throw anything into the scales that would have just been another straw which might have disturbed the course of events. That being so, we had to wait until the votes had been registered. Saturday was a holiday; Sunday was a holiday; and we required one clear day's notice. Notice had either to be given on Friday, which would have been before the referendum results, or immediately after the referendum results, which was on Monday.

    It is true that in so calculating, I anticipated that it would interfere with certain engagements to which I have committed myself, such as attending a conference of Commonwealth socialist leaders in London, many of whom will perhaps have fond memories of the Member for Anson. I do not intend to break this engagement as I think it is useful to the country. The people should know that the Communist line of a reactionary, corrupt, effete and decadent Government should be debunked and utterly exploded.

    We have decided on the time - a full five hours without a tea-break. It was carefully calculated to give a full day's sitting. One p.m. to 6.00 p.m. is equivalent to 2.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m. minus half an hour tea-break. It is as simple as that arithmetically. Having decided that it would be at 6.00 p.m. and discovering that I had some time to spare, I decided this evening to thank publicly the many social and civic organisations which took a stand and helped to break the Communist myth of the masses supporting whatever balderdash, the tirades of abuse that they heaped on this Assembly. I make no apologies for this either to Members of this House or to the public. What we have done is in

Column: 640

the best interests of the country. And what we, intend to do is in the best interests of the country.

    Sir, the Member for Anson makes the mistake of confusing his propaganda line. He accuses me of another joy jaunt, it is a mistake which Mr Woodhull and other Members of the Barisan Sosialis bitterly paid for when they appeared before the United Nations Committee of Seventeen. The P.A.P., of which I am proud to have been a member all this time, does not change its colours and its habits. We move in a deliberate and calculated manner in the interests of the people, regardless of abuse and regardless of tirades. They leave us completely unmoved, and I am glad to say they leave the people completely unmoved too.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye rose -

    Mr Speaker: Dr Toh, in reply.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, it is utterly dishonest of the Opposition to say that they did not have time to decide on the future of the blank votes when the whole of Singapore know that they have been campaigning for blank votes ever since April 1962. Surely when they campaigned for blank votes, they knew what was the purpose of the blank votes. Do they mean to say that now they want more time to consider the future of these blank votes? Do they mean to say that they never knew what the blank votes, which they asked the voters to cast, were meant for? That is a piece of utter dishonesty and insincerity which is very obviously shown here by the Opposition. We have called a full day's sitting of this House so that the House can utilise five hours to decide on the future of these blank votes. In particular, Members of the U.P.P., the Barisan Sosialis and the Workers' Party should have decided long ago why they ever called for blank votes to be cast. Having called for blank votes for the past few months, they now have the audacity to come to this House and say that they want more time to debate on these blank votes.

Column: 641

REPORT ON SINGAPORE NATIONAL REFERENDUM
(CMD. 18 OF 1962)
UNCERTAIN AND UNMARKED BALLOT PAPERS


    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, in moving this motion, we are formally bringing to an end a decisive phase of our history. I hope I did the right thing in doing this House the courtesy of staying behind personally to move this motion. The constitutional struggle for merger and Malaysia is over. The struggle began with a special sitting of this Assembly on 22nd of July last year, when the lines were drawn between the sides for and against merger and the issues were joined. It went on for a full, grim and relentless 14 months. On the constitutional plane, the Communists, fighting through their united front organisations like the Barisan Sosialis, the Communist-led trade unions, the Old Boys' Associations, the Rural Dwellers and Country People's Associations, have all lost. Whether they will start an unconstitutional struggle is a matter for them. Suffice it to say that they embark on unconstitutional actions at their own peril.

    My Party colleagues, who have experience of the ways of the Malayan Communist Party and its subsidiary organisations-

    Mr David Marshall rose -

Column: 642



    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    Mr David Marshall: Point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir. Would it be appropriate at this juncture to take the point of order that the motion which I understand the Prime Minister will be moving is ultra vires?

    Mr Speaker: It would be convenient, I think, if we hear the Prime Minister. He will probably touch on that aspect in his speech. I do not know. But it may be more convenient for the Prime Minister to complete his speech and then I will allow the Member to raise his point of order.

    The Prime Minister: My Party colleagues, who have experience of the ways of the Malayan Communist Party and its subsidiary organisations, tell me that there will be a great deal of criticism and self-criticism amongst leaders of every rank of the underground and open-front Communist organisations. Errors will be analysed and the perpetrators of these errors chastised, general rectification instituted and the scapegoats quietly found and sacrificed in the hope of some eventual victory. This is the moment of bitter truth for them and many aspiring young, up and coming Marxist theoreticians have blotted their copy-books and prejudiced their place of honour in the Communist hierarchy. Something has gone wrong somewhere and socialist realism was brought home with bitter unpleasantness in the early hours of Sunday, 2nd September. Of course, the revolution will go on, and they will try to whip things up again. But we are prepared to meet them on any issue.

    It does not really require erudition in Marxism-Leninism to see why and where they went wrong, and where they invited disaster. The simple lesson of the last 14 months is that, however ruthless, however clever, and however organised the steel framework of Communist-trained cadres can be, the attack on the enemy will fail if the basic analysis is wrong. The most fundamental analysis is to define who are the people, and who are the enemies of the people. To fight nationalist groups even if they are decried in Communist

Column: 643

dogma as bourgeois democratic elements, at a time when the common enemy is in Communist theory also still Colonial Imperialism and its reactionary supporters, is to invite disaster. The obvious objective for any socialist party, whether of the Communist or non-Communist variety, is the solidarity of the nation through merger, and the achievement of freedom. The right thing was co-operation with all patriotic nationalist groups, however bourgeois or wavering social democrats they may be. But to choose, as the Communists and their front organisations did, to fight against the national solidarity of the races, against merger, and against freedom consequent with merger was a fatal error. Worse still, to choose to fight patriotic nationalists and to seek as allies in a united front, opportunists, adventurers and reactionary Right-wing elements was to invite humiliation and inevitable disaster.

    Socialist realism demands the accurate appraisal of persons and groups and to name them accurately. All their skilful tactics of abuse and vilification cannot turn a nationalist Party into a pro-colonialist, and having failed, to turn it into a neo-colonialist, and that having failed, to make it into a Fascist Party. This is a practice of futile self-deception, trying to mould facts into their preconceived theories, believing that the Government of the P.A.P. has become effete and decadent, turned pro-colonialist and then turned neo-colonialist and then fascist.

    In calling for blank votes those Members of the Opposition called for votes against merger, against the national unity of our people, and against freedom through merger. Had they had the courage to go through with their line of complete merger, they might have at least saved themselves this final humiliation

Column: 644

and they might at least have been defeated doing the honourable thing. But they were caught by their own dishonest propaganda lines. Publicly they called for complete merger. Privately they said merger was a sell-out of the Chinese in Singapore to the Malays in the Federation. So the more complete the merger, the more the sell-out.

    Had the "B" votes been more than the "A" votes, as a result of the blank ballots that they called for, it would have been the duty of this House to take note of the majority of "B" votes. However, over 71 per cent voted "A". In these circumstances, under section 29 of the Referendum Ordinance, I - move that those Opposition Members who did not support the - White Paper and called for blank votes should now be asked to declare publicly whether they wish the blank votes to be allocated to Alternative A or B or C. This is the constitutional process. The unconditional rejoinder, of course, is to take direct action outside. That is a, matter for them to decide.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move*.


    *The motion reads as follows:

    That this Assembly takes note of the Report of the Superintendent of the Singapore National Referendum as contained in Paper Cmd.18 of 1962 and in accordance with section 29 of the Singapore National Referendum Ordinance, 1962, that the House decides-

    (1) that 2,370 uncertain ballot papers should be deemed to be votes for Alternatives A as indicated in the ballot paper; and

    (2) that 144,077 unmarked ballot papers should be decided in accordance with the wishes of those Opposition Assemblymen who opposed the amended White Paper merger proposals and calls upon them to decide to which of the Alternatives A, B and C the blank votes should be allocated.


    Mr Speaker: Before I propose the Question, the Member for Anson has, indicated that he wishes to rise on a point of order.

    Mr David Marshall: The point of order is a very simple one, Sir. That the second part of this motion is ultra vires, and I will be very brief. What I refer to is one which is curious in any other country but anticipated from the corkscrew P.A.P.,. that the 144,077 unmarked ballot papers, should be decided in accordance with, the wishes of those Opposition Assemblymen who opposed the amended White Paper merger proposals and who are called upon to decide to which of the Alternatives A, B and C the blank votes should be allocated.

Column: 645



    Mr Speaker, Sir, may I draw your attention to the provisions of section 29:

    `Any person whose ballot paper-

    (a) is unmarked; or

    (b) is uncertain

shall be deemed to be a person who accepts or is willing to accept the decision of the Legislative Assembly on the matter referred for the referendum.

    Mr Speaker, it must be clear that the authority given by this statute is to the Assembly - abide by "the decision of the Assembly". I say that the second part is ultra vires in that it does not seek the decision of the Assembly, but seeks from the Opposition a decision by the request of the Assembly. I am sure, Mr Speaker, that we are fortunate here that you yourself are legally trained, that you appreciate the existence of the legal maxim known as "delegatus non potest delegate." The agent cannot delegate his powers. This applies to the Assembly as well as to any other both which has statutory authority. I say that this Assembly cannot delegate the authority given by section 29 to take a decision itself on the provisions of section 29 as to what is to be done with the blank votes. Above all, it cannot seek to pass it on to any group whether within or without the Assembly, quite apart from the dishonesty and the absurdity of asking people, who say they do not want section 29, to say, "Now, you work it," which I can see from the grin on the face of the Minister for Education just suits his corkscrew temperament.

    Mr Speaker, I ask for a ruling that that part of the motion of the Prime Minister which calls upon the Assembly to request the Opposition to make a decision, is ultra vires the powers of this Assembly, is illegal and contrary to the provisions of section 29.

    Mr Speaker: Would the Prime Minister like to assist the Chair?

1.45 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: Yes, if I may, Mr Speaker, Sir, I had anticipated quite wrongly, Mr Speaker, Sir, the learned treatises and dissertations on constitutional procedures and processes. All I heard is one tag of dog Latin - delegatus non potest delegare. Well, we are doing nothing of the sort. We are

Column: 646

not saying delegatus delegare. What we are saying is that we in this Assembly have the right to decide, and we are deciding that we shall abstain and allow the Opposition to decide. Whether it is constitutional or unconstitutional to abstain depends upon the rules of this Assembly. There are Assemblies and Legislative Chambers where the right to abstain does not exist; where when you are present at the time a division is called, you will vote. If we had an Assembly of that nature, perhaps the Member for Anson might be on firmer ground. But I am sorry that he has not devoted more time and care before taking up this question of the propriety of the motion.
